对香港冲击立法会大楼事件 三大央媒重磅发声
translation:
In response to the violent attack on the Legislative Council building in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region on July 1, the People's Daily, Xinhua News Agency, and CCTV's "News Network" made a strong statement: Hong Kong cannot withstand the torment and internal strife, and Hong Kong's rule of law cannot be challenged. Violent acts must be severely punished in accordance with the law!

People's Daily commentator: We firmly support the SAR government in pursuing serious violations to the end

July 1 is a happy day for people from all walks of life in Hong Kong to commemorate Hong Kong’s return to the motherland and the establishment of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region. However, some extreme radicals violently attacked the Legislative Council building on the pretext of opposing the amendment of relevant regulations of the SAR government. This is a serious violation of the rule of law in Hong Kong, a great damage to Hong Kong's social order, and a blatant challenge to the bottom line of "one country, two systems."

They used iron rods and iron cages to destroy the glass exterior walls of the Legislative Council building, used toxic chemical powder to attack the police, forced their way into the Legislative Council building, and wantonly damaged the solemn chamber and the SAR emblem...these are acts of lawless violence. This behavior is very shocking, sad and angry! No country or society will tolerate this. The central government firmly supports Chief Executive Carrie Lam and the SAR government in administering the law in accordance with the law, and firmly supports the Hong Kong police in strictly enforcing the law, pursuing illegal activities to the end, and ensuring social order and citizen safety.

title: Interview: Radical protesters responsible for violence in Hong Kong, expert says
最新铁证！美国在香港搞“政治731”实验，上千大学生成“小白鼠”
translation:
Investigating the paper's author team revealed more.
For example, a man named David Yang, who has an Asian face, is officially an assistant professor in the Department of Economics at Harvard University, and many of his "research results" involve social interaction and protests. What's even more coincidental is that many co-authors are also "contributors" to this paper on Hong Kong.
After looking at his social media accounts, I discovered more.
In a tweet on June 15, 2019, he mentioned an article published by the team on the London School of Political Science website two years ago, which stated that the mainland has a so-called "triple dilemma" in Hong Kong, and that protests are detrimental to maintaining Hong Kong's political stability is "vital".
Is doing things in Hong Kong conducive to Hong Kong's stability? Isn’t this similar to Pelosi’s “beautiful landscape”?
The article, which Yang co-wrote, claimed: "As long as the people of Hong Kong threaten credible protests, Beijing can be restrained."
The use of protests to force the passage of Article 23 of the Basic Law was called a "successful case" by the paper, and in the author's eloquent article on the LSE website, there is even this statement: "Article 23 of the Basic Law Doing nothing is important to Hong Kong's stability and "one country, two systems." Protests are a source of stability, not instability. Beijing's attempts to pass national security legislation within the framework of Article 23 of the Basic Law are actually a source of instability. "
Translate: Obstructing the legislation under Article 23 is a matter of abiding by the Basic Law and safeguarding "one country, two systems"; establishing national security legislation based on Article 23 is illegal and is not conducive to the stability of Hong Kong.
What is even more obvious is that the views of several authors of the paper were also included in the article on the LSE website. They interviewed thousands of students who participated in the "Occupy Central" movement, and based on the survey results of 1,500 of them, The so-called "evidence" that young people in Hong Kong have become radicalized was obtained: 88% of people consider themselves Hong Kongers rather than Chinese; 22% support the use of violence to pursue political rights in Hong Kong. And when they "encouraged" students to express anonymously, the proportion of those who supported violence reached 40%.
The LSE official website also stated that "this article represents the views of the author of the paper and has nothing to do with LSE."
David Yang called the South China Morning Post's 2017 report on gang violence on the streets of Hong Kong a "Nice report".
On the day when the black riots broke out in Hong Kong in 2019, he retweeted articles from accounts supporting the riots and "praised": "Collective action is the most spectacular scene showing human power."
From 2017 to 2018, David Yang was also one of the main disseminators of Xinjiang-related rumors. He also reposted social media tweets from the famous lie maker Adrian Zenz. This has to make people wonder, how many Zheng Guoen and others are there in Western university circles? What role does Yang play in this circle?

HK protests expose Western media bias
最新铁证！美国在香港搞“政治731”实验，上千大学生成“小白鼠”
translation:
This paper focuses on the so-called "protests" with clear purpose and specificity since Hong Kong's return to the motherland, citing the so-called arguments and euphemistically calling them "the spirit of Hong Kong's democratic struggle." And they tend to refer to the anniversary of Hong Kong's return as "the anniversary of Hong Kong's handover to China."
We have to wonder about their real purpose of doing this research: after observing a phenomenon, draw their own conclusions through research and analysis, or in the name of research, to be the organizers, planners, and motivators of the "color revolution" ?
Coincidentally, their intentions were "revealed" later in the article.
In what the authors call “overcoming difficulties,” they mention that “because Hong Kong’s ‘democratic’ people have a tradition of protest, existing protests allow us to gain forward-looking perspectives in real time.”
By choosing the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology as the research target, they "can use incentives to obtain in advance the opinions of more than 1,200 college students on their classmates' participation in the upcoming demonstrations" and thus "randomly process information on some of them, and Lead to a posteriori perspectives and finally, “lead out students’ own protest participation behavior.”
The paper concludes that within a political movement, incentives to attend one protest increase attendance at subsequent protests; one-time incentive mobilization has positive consequences, while mobilization at the social network level is very important for sustained political participation. important.
In the appendix of the 2019 version of the paper, we see a questionnaire "tailored" by the authors of the paper for Hong Kong students. There is also content suggesting that the interviewed students donate their remuneration to the "Hong Kong Independence" organization "Hong Kong People's Liberation Army".
In addition, in the paper they also designed related questions about the Hong Kong subway. Unsurprisingly, during the riots in Hong Kong in 2019, the most targeted target of the thugs was the Hong Kong subway. In addition, the paper further claims that its research complied with ethical requirements during the operation: "Participating in the July 1st demonstrations was clearly legal and peaceful in all years before the study; the demonstrations we studied remained peaceful, and during the two years of the study No protesters were prosecuted for any crimes during the year; our experiment was small relative to the size of the July 1 demonstrations we studied."

香港七一游行500余名被捕者悉数获释，有人身藏攻击性武器
translation:
The central government respects the rights of Hong Kong citizens to express their opinions, but any form of so-called "referendum" in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region has no constitutional legal basis, is illegal, and is invalid.
The overseas edition of People's Daily published an article today criticizing the July 1st demonstrations in Hong Kong. According to reports, Hong Kong's radical opposition organizations "Scholar Citizen Thought" and the Federation of Students rehearsed "Occupy Central" on the evening of July 1, illegally trying to force the Hong Kong SAR government to accept "citizen nominations" that were not in compliance with the Basic Law. People from all walks of life in Hong Kong pointed out that the opposition first used the illegal "referendum" to build momentum, and then illegally "Occupy Central". They were kidnapping public opinion in order to challenge "one country, two systems", ignore the mainstream public opinion in Hong Kong society, and harm the interests of Hong Kong's 7 million citizens.

Famous person: "Don't do anything illegal"

The report also interviewed many Hong Kong people to express their views on the matter. Chen Yongqi, a member of the Standing Committee of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, told the People's Daily that he was young and opposed many things, but no one should do anything illegal. The so-called "referendum" launched by the "Occupy Central" group a few days ago "can't see the actual number of people voting and whether the votes are duplicated, so there must be something wrong."

Cheng Yaotang, executive chairman of the Hong Kong Celebration Committee, told the People's Daily that the most important thing for citizens to express their demands is to abide by the law, and instigating violations of the law and causing trouble are not Hong Kong's core values. Tam Yiu-chung, chairman of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of China and member of the Legislative Council, pointed out that the voices from all walks of life against "Occupy Central" are very loud, and he does not understand why the opposition still goes against public opinion. "Occupy Central" is blatantly illegal. It not only blocks traffic, but also affects people's daily lives and poses a danger to people's lives and property. He was worried that the situation would eventually get out of control, and urged the opposition to think carefully and "illegal things should not be done." Ip Kwok-him, convener of the DAB Legislative Council caucus, pointed out that everyone, including students, should not engage in illegal and violent behaviors. The police should act in accordance with the law.

The numbers are false and there is a black hand behind it.

The People's Daily stated that the "Democratic Front", which launched the "July 1" march in Hong Kong, claimed that the number of people marching this year was more than five times that announced by the police. This shows that the "Democratic Front" is crazy about counting (big numbers). The newspaper cited an article by Wen Pingli published by Hong Kong's Wen Wei Po and pointed out that in fact, the police used a scientific and rigorous statistical method to count the number of people in the march, which was well-founded. The opposition insists that this is nothing more than a "self-fulfilling lie", telling and directing its own lies. Who else would believe such numbers?

Follow-up: More than 500 demonstrators in Hong Kong have been released

According to the People's Daily, the Hong Kong police have released more than 500 arrested demonstrators. The police issued warning notices to 486 people who participated in the "July 1 Parade", and 25 others were granted bail pending investigation and reported to the police from late July to early August. The police said that three arrested men aged 18 to 68 were found with screwdrivers, knives or folding knives on their bodies and were arrested on suspicion of "possession of offensive weapons", while another 21-year-old woman was arrested on suspicion of "assaulting a police officer" .

title: 香港愤慨立法会遭冲击 港媒称下一站是旺角
translation: "Do you think that the incident that occurred in the Legislative Council in the early hours of Wednesday morning marks the complete failure of the non-violent principle of 'Occupy Central'?" Yesterday, 82% of the respondents chose "Yes" in a poll on the Hong Kong "South China Morning Post" website with this title. ". From late night on the 18th to early morning on the 19th, the Hong Kong Legislative Council building was violently attacked by dozens of demonstrators wearing masks. Many glass doors were destroyed, and one of them briefly broke into the Legislative Council building. The relevant meeting of the Legislative Council originally scheduled to be held on the 19th was forced to be rescheduled. Since the incident occurred on the day when law enforcement officers were clearing occupied roads in the Admiralty area, some people suspected that the radical demonstrators who stormed the Legislative Council were retaliating for the above actions. There were also "Occupy Central" people who suspected that the perpetrators were "ghosts" and claimed that the move was "Framing and framing" "Occupy Central". After this "restless night", the Hong Kong government, establishment and pan-democratic lawmakers unanimously condemned the violent attacks, while the student leader who led the "occupation" said those who stormed the Legislative Council "should not be condemned." On the 19th, Hong Kong media such as "Ming Pao" urged students to "persuad students to quit" while urging the police to "enforce the law decisively." Under the "cloud of Occupy Central", Hong Kong spent its 53rd day of "occupation" in this way. The focus of the 54th day is Mong Kok, where law enforcement officers are about to launch a similar "road clearing" operation.

香港修例风波回望：当青年被绑上暴力战车
translation:
Last November, black-clad thugs, including some students, occupied the Chinese University of Hong Kong and the Hong Kong Polytechnic University. They occupied bridges and threw objects at traffic thoroughfares, threw petrol bombs at the police, and confronted the police with bows and arrows. They used the campus as a "battlefield." The Chinese University of Hong Kong was even called a "violent university" by the society. However, the president of the student union of the school even shouted: "I think this (title) is an affirmation of CUHK students, and I am proud of being a 'big' student."
"Many young people learn to break the law before they know what law-abiding is." Liang Meifen, a member of the Hong Kong Basic Law Committee of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, said bluntly that the so-called "violating the law to achieve justice" "romanticizes" and "heroizes" the way of committing crimes, inducing people to There are many young people who have nothing to do.
In order to tightly kidnap Hong Kong youth on the stalled chariot, the anti-China and anti-Hong Kong forces are trying their best to excuse illegal acts and justify crimes. They trick young people into saying "leaving a criminal record will make life more exciting" and instigate them to ignore the law and attack the police.
Huang Xihua, a Hong Kong social worker who was born in 1990, has been following the entire legislative controversy with a cold eye. He pointed out: "Hong Kong has always been praised for its rule of law. Hong Kong youth who were born and raised here will not fail to understand the importance of the rule of law to Hong Kong. But under the endorsement of the theory of 'justice without error', they knew the law and broke the law."
October 1, 2019 is a day for the whole country to celebrate the 70th anniversary of the founding of New China. On this day, a large number of thugs violently attacked police officers in Tsuen Wan, Hong Kong. Video from the scene showed a thug wearing blue gloves and holding a shield wildly hitting the police officer with an iron rod in his hand, and the police officer was forced to shoot and wound him. The person who was shot was only 18 years old.
Anyone with a modicum of common sense and rationality knows that violent attacks on the government will be severely punished, and attacking police officers is a felony. However, the anti-China and destabilizing forces in Hong Kong instigate young people to be "righteous men" and "martyrs" to attack the government, attack the police, block roads and set fires, and do everything possible to cause bloodshed. This 18-year-old middle school student became a "cannon fodder" in a muddle-headed manner.

外交部：香港示威者冲击立法会是践踏法治、危害社会秩序的严重违法行为
translation:
On July 1, a violent attack on the Legislative Council building occurred in the Hong Kong SAR. Foreign Ministry spokesman Geng Shuang said on the 2nd that this was a serious illegal act that trampled on the rule of law and endangered social order. China strongly condemns this. The central government firmly supports the Hong Kong SAR government and police in handling the incident in accordance with the law.
According to reports, the United States, the United Kingdom, and the European Union issued a statement regarding the Hong Kong demonstrators' attack on the Legislative Council, stating that the people of Hong Kong should have the right to peaceful protest and should avoid violence. At present, it is more important to exercise restraint. Geng Shuang responded: "If the violent attack on the Legislative Council in Hong Kong happened in the United States or Europe, how would they handle it? Will they let it go? Everyone has seen on TV the scenes of police officers in the United States and Europe dealing with violent law enforcement. . Why do they not only fail to condemn the same thing when it happens in Hong Kong, but also make irresponsible remarks and point fingers, seemingly impartially advocating for the right to peaceful protest and calling for the avoidance of violence? This is completely naked double standards, extremely hypocritical and ugly. !”
Geng Shuang reiterated that Hong Kong is a special administrative region of China and Hong Kong affairs are purely China's internal affairs. China expresses strong dissatisfaction and firm opposition to relevant countries' gross interference in Hong Kong affairs and China's internal affairs. We once again urge relevant countries to be cautious in their words and deeds and not to interfere in Hong Kong's internal affairs in any way, not to embolden violent lawbreakers in any form, and not to issue Any misleading signals, don’t make any wrong moves.

title: Hong Kong is protesting a China extradition bill, but violence could open divisions | CNN
香港：宣誓辱国辱华“港独”分子冲击立法会罪名成立
translation:
On November 2, 2016, the former Legislative Council-elect of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Leung Chung-hang and Yau Wai-chen, together with three former parliamentary assistants, barged into the Legislative Council conference room, brought their own loudspeakers and tried to forcefully swear an oath. In the chaos, many security personnel were injured, 5 The person was later charged with participating in an illegal assembly. Hong Kong's Kowloon City Magistrates' Court issued a verdict this morning: five people were found guilty of illegal assembly.
On October 12, 2016, at the swearing-in ceremony for members of the new Hong Kong Legislative Council, "Youth New Deal" elected members Leung Chung-hang and Yau Waizhen displayed the slogans "HONGKONG IS NOT CHINA" (Hong Kong is not China) and "Hong Kong independence", declaring allegiance to " "Hong Kong Nation", and added words that insulted the country and China, pronouncing "CHINA" as "China"; Yau Wai-chen even made a profanity and pronounced "REPUBLIC" (Republic) as "REFXXXING" (a curse word). The Secretary-General of the Legislative Council, who was responsible for administering the oath that day, immediately stated that he could not administer the oath for the two of them.
On November 2 of the same year, Leung Chung-hang and Yau Wai-chen forced their way into the Legislative Council chamber without the approval of the Chairman of the Legislative Council and attempted to take an oath on their own. During the process, they insulted, pushed, and kicked security guards, resulting in injuries to six security guards and one security guard. Lost consciousness in the chaos. Legislative Council Chairman Leung Jun-yin subsequently called the police, and five people including Leung Chung-heng and Yau Waizhen were charged with illegal assembly.

title: Hong Kong society choruses against violence escalation on National Day
涉嫌暴力冲击香港立法会，12人已被警方拘捕！
translation:
"If violence is used, Hong Kong will definitely collapse."
According to the New York Times, Cecilia Zhang is the kind of Chinese who might be considered sympathetic to Hong Kong protesters—she studied at a prestigious American school, has been working in the financial industry in Hong Kong for the past four years, and has not moved back to the mainland. Intend. But in fact, she thinks it's time for those protesters to go home. "With strikes and school strikes, Hong Kong's economy will be very ugly this year." The newspaper said that many educated Chinese people believe that protesters should work hard to rebuild Hong Kong. Hong Kong was once a beacon of prosperity, but now it is losing its luster.
"Social disputes continue, and if violence is used, Hong Kong will definitely collapse." Sing Tao Daily quoted Wu Yingxiang, chairman of Hong Kong's Hopewell Holdings, as saying on the 3rd that continued social disputes will damage Hong Kong's business environment, and if it turns into "mob politics" " will undermine investor confidence. Hong Kong's "Sing Tao Daily" published an editorial on the 3rd, saying that just as Hong Kong people don't like to travel to violent places, overseas people will also be greatly reduced in their willingness to visit Hong Kong when they see international news articles and conspicuous reports on Hong Kong's violent attacks. It affects the employment opportunities of many people. Popular Japanese boy band KAT-TUN has canceled its first performance in Hong Kong scheduled for this Friday.
The newspaper said that the current situation in Hong Kong has a lot to do with the long-term propaganda of pan-democrats. They have opened Pandora's box and instilled in young people the so-called fallacy of "violating the law to achieve justice." This toxic thought, after several years of "latency", finally played a role in this incident. An editorial in Hong Kong's "Toutiao Daily" on the 3rd stated that Hong Kong society must now choose between unstoppable conflict or the restoration of rational dialogue. The former will only bring endless violence and continue to sink, while the latter can bring Hong Kong out of its predicament and allow everyone to live a normal and peaceful life again.

title: Hong Kong jails 12 people for over the storming of the legislature in 2019 protests
Commentary: Hong Kong's status as int'l financial hub should be cherished
环球时报：香港现七一游行，国家不可能让步
translation:
The mentality of Hong Kong society today is very complex. In addition to being generally valued, the issue of democracy has also become a special psychological fulcrum for some people when the gap between developed mainland regions and Hong Kong is narrowing. Hong Kong's living standards have long been much higher than those on the mainland, and many people are used to facing the pride of mainlanders. Nowadays, many people's sense of superiority is under attack, and Western-style "democracy" has become the thing that some Hong Kong people identify as "most different from the mainland."

In today's value system, such differences may make them feel "proud." They will think that you in the mainland cannot hold the "July 1st Parade", but we can. You value political unity, but we can "confront" the central government. These confrontational activities make some people feel "high-mainland". They may not attach great importance to the results, but are willing to participate, thus being exploited by the radical opposition.

The different political systems of the mainland and Hong Kong seem destined to have some points of intersection and friction. How to manage the differences between the two sides has become a challenge to the country. It is very important to study Hong Kong's chaotic July 1st demonstrations clearly, distinguish between what the radical opposition demands and what ordinary citizens are thinking, and not be kidnapped by Hong Kong's various demonstrations. Such stability is very important.

There is no contradiction between adhering to the principles of the Basic Law and responding to the numerous demands of ordinary citizens. Taking care of the emotions of ordinary Hong Kong citizens should not be at the expense of increasing the distance or even antagonism between the mainland and Hong Kong people. The country does not have to expect too much from Hong Kong society, and it must be able to withstand demonstrations and demonstrations there. If this is the case, the "July 1st Parade" in Hong Kong is nothing, and even if there are local conflicts between police and citizens, it is nothing significant.

As long as those who participate in the demonstrations confirm that the country cannot retreat at all through this method, the political enthusiasm gathered by this kind of protest will eventually decline, and demonstrations will become a daily thing in Hong Kong, and as a kind of political culture, it will remain tepid. The presence of fire. Therefore, for protests such as the July 1st Parade, adapting to them, not taking them too seriously, and encouraging illegal actions to be dealt with in accordance with the law should be the basic starting point for the country to formulate strategies.

title: 涉嫌暴力冲击香港立法会，12人已被警方拘捕！
translation:
Geng Shuang: Is the British police's response to the London riots repression?
Agence France-Presse reported on the 3rd that British Prime Minister Theresa May told members of Congress that day that she directly expressed her "concerns" to China about protecting Hong Kong's autonomy. May admitted she was "surprised" by the violent demonstrations at Hong Kong's Legislative Council, but stressed that hundreds of thousands of Hong Kong people marched "peacefully and lawfully". Agence France-Presse stated that a few hours before May's remarks, Beijing had just expressed its strong dissatisfaction and firm opposition to British Foreign Secretary Hunt's erroneous remarks on Hong Kong, and revealed that both London and Beijing had lodged stern representations with the British side.
Hunt claimed on the 2nd that the "Sino-British Joint Declaration" is still legally binding and if it is not implemented, "the consequences will be very serious." The British "Times" said that his threatening remarks made relations between Britain and China tense. Beijing had previously hit back at Hunter's words and deeds for two consecutive days, warning the UK not to interfere in China's internal affairs. "He (Hunter) seems to be still immersed in the illusion of the British colonists in the past, and is still obsessed with the bad habit of dictating the affairs of other countries from a superior position. He still does not want to repent and continues to talk nonsense. I will simply say a few more words today." Geng Shuang said on the 3rd that the British side has no sovereignty, no governance power, and no supervision power over Hong Kong after its return. There is no so-called "responsibility" at all. "I would like to ask Mr. Hunt, during the British colonial rule of Hong Kong, what kind of democracy was there in Hong Kong? Hong Kong people did not even have the right to march on the streets."
Hunter ignored the facts and ignored the violent attack on the Legislative Council by extremists, but urged the Hong Kong government not to use the vandalism during the protests as an excuse for "repression." Geng Shuang asked three sharp questions: If the British Parliament is besieged, broken into, and destroyed, will the British government let it go and sit idly by? If, as Mr. Hunt says, this is democracy, does he think that the police who closely guard the British Parliament should be withdrawn and the demonstrators who have always stood opposite the Parliament should be allowed to enter the Parliament? Does he also think that the British police's handling of the riots in London in August 2011 was repression?
On the 2nd, Peter, a British man who has worked and lived in mainland China and Hong Kong for at least 35 years, bluntly said in an interview with the Associated Press that if in Western countries such as the United Kingdom and the United States, thugs would face real bullets instead of rubber bullets, almost Ten or even hundreds of people could be killed or injured. He called the thugs' damage to the democratic process in Hong Kong and the mainland "the most tragic thing."
Britain, which is stuck in the quagmire of Brexit, is currently facing a battle for prime minister. One of the candidates is Hunt, who has frequently used the Hong Kong issue to show his toughness in recent days. Another candidate, former Foreign Secretary Johnson, seems to understand this well and is not willing to lag behind. British Reuters reported that Johnson claimed on the 3rd that he warned Beijing not to abandon "one country, two systems"
On the 3rd, the head of the Commissioner's Office of the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Hong Kong solemnly requested the British side to face up to the reality that Hong Kong has returned to the motherland 22 years ago, immediately stop interfering in Hong Kong affairs and China's internal affairs, and stop going further down the wrong path.

title: 香港13人冲击立法会一案改判 即时监禁8到13个月
translation:
According to Hong Kong Wenhui.com, on August 15, the case of 13 demonstrators convicted of storming the Hong Kong SAR Legislative Council in June 2014 was announced to have been changed. The judge finally ruled that based on the level of violence in the case and everyone's attitudes, the previous sentence of social service order was obviously too light. This time, starting from 15 months' imprisonment, the defendants were sentenced to 8 to 13 months' imprisonment.

Wenhui.com reported that demonstrators stormed the Legislative Council building when the Finance Committee of the Legislative Council was reviewing funding for the early stage development of the Northeast New Territories in June 2014. A large number of demonstrators hit the door of the Legislative Council with bamboo poles and other objects. In February last year, the Eastern District Magistrates' Court found 13 defendants guilty of "participating in an illegal assembly" but not guilty of "attempting to enter by force". They were sentenced to 80 to 150 hours of community service orders.

The Department of Justice applied to the Court of Appeal for a sentence review yesterday (14th), stating that the situation that day was extremely serious and the violent behavior of several defendants was close to the critical point of riot. Only imprisonment is the appropriate sentence. Wan Dehao, Senior Assistant Public Prosecution Commissioner of the Department of Justice, stated in court that the crime in this case was extremely serious. Not only the arrested persons were involved, but also a large-scale illegal assembly of more than 100 people. They were "complicit in committing the crime" and "a collective action". Taking advantage of their large numbers and ignoring the police presence inside the Legislative Council, the demonstrators used bamboo branches, umbrellas and metal tools removed from trolleys to force open the glass door of the Legislative Council building. The Legislative Council is an important symbol of the rule of law in Hong Kong. The large-scale attack by demonstrators is a blatant challenge to law and order, a disregard for public order, and a serious illegal act. The situation may turn into a riot.

Clearance operation in Mong Kok causes concern

Huang Yangda flatly denied planning to attack the Legislative Council. However, his affiliated "Hot Blood Times" continued to publish articles online on the 19th, supporting that the incident was just hitting a dead object and not hurting anyone, and that it was a reasonable behavior. He praised the thugs for "they can muster the courage to try to escalate the action and break the gap." very impressive". translation:
The "Democratic Front" declared that it was "relentless in its evil intentions" and still attempted to create a binary opposition between the central government, the SAR government and the so-called civil society. It played the card of tragedy, created an image of being forced to disband, and concealed the fact that it was abandoned.
The Democratic Front was first abandoned by the times. Today, when the international situation is undergoing profound and complex changes, Hong Kong, as a special administrative region of the country, must of course stand with the country to safeguard national security and defend national interests in a complex multilateral international environment. Especially after the central government took the initiative to fill Hong Kong's legal loopholes in maintaining national security in 2020 in response to the international situation and the situation in Hong Kong, maintaining national security has become an important issue in Hong Kong. Of course, the "Han" organization will only end up being abandoned by the times.
Secondly, the Democratic Front was abandoned by its former fellow travelers. As early as early March this year, after news spread that the Democratic Front might be banned according to law, its members cut their seats one after another and announced that they would terminate their participation in the work of the Democratic Front. The "Democratic Front" groups quickly shrunk from 48 to less than 10 before disbandment, leaving behind the radical political group and its satellite organizations of the last two conveners. Members are jumping ship one after another. Is it because the world is so cold and they throw it away after use, or are they cutting off their robes and severing their righteousness to protect themselves wisely? On the bright side, these pan-democratic groups participating in the "Democratic Front" also have legal concepts. Faced with possible legal liabilities, of course they choose to cut themselves off to protect themselves. When the members dispersed, the platform of the "Democratic Front" naturally collapsed.
In the end, the "Democratic Front" was abandoned by the Hong Kong people. As the initiator, leader, and operator of the "July 1 Parade" and the "Amendment Movement" demonstrations in Hong Kong for many years, the "Democratic Front" is well aware of whether these demonstrations have brought a good reputation or a bad influence to Hong Kong. After experiencing a series of incidents such as the "revision storm", the disbandment of "Hong Kong independence" organizations after the promulgation of the Hong Kong National Security Law, the imprisonment of "Hong Kong independence" elements, and the flight of others, many Hong Kong people have seen more To make it clear: what kind of organization and what kind of behavior are really good for Hong Kong, and what kind of organization and what kind of behavior are specifically bringing chaos to Hong Kong. Now that Hong Kong people have seen clearly, the disbandment of the Democratic Front is the inevitable result of the development of Hong Kong's social situation.

title: In Pictures: Hong Kong protesters storm government headquarters | Hong Kong Protests | Al Jazeera
2019年冲击香港立法会大楼12人暴动罪成
translation:
The Hong Kong police announced on the 16th that in the case of demonstrators attacking the Legislative Council (Legislative Council) building of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region on July 1, 2019, the 14 defendants involved were found guilty after trial. The case was sentenced in the Hong Kong District Court on the 16th. Among them, 12 The man was sentenced to 54 months to 82 months in prison for rioting.
Chief Inspector Wong Chi-tang of the Police Organized Crime and Triad Investigation Bureau said that on the afternoon of July 1, 2019, a large number of demonstrators gathered outside the Legislative Council Building and used iron cages, iron bars, etc. to attack the glass outside the Legislative Council Building, and then Break in and cause massive destruction. After investigation, the police charged 14 defendants, including 12 men and 2 women, aged 19 to 40 at the time of the crime, for "riot", "criminal damage" and "violation of administrative instructions". All were found guilty after trial, and 12 of them were sentenced to prison terms ranging from 54 months to 82 months.
Huang Zhiteng said that the relevant cases were planned and premeditated, and he believed that the court's sentence could reflect the seriousness of the case and also act as a deterrent. He said that the Legislative Council has a unique constitutional status and symbolic significance. In addition to destroying objects in the Legislative Council building, the demonstrators also tried to weaken and overthrow Hong Kong's constitution and attack Hong Kong's rule of law. The judge also pointed out in the ruling that this was a serious case. .
Huang Zhiteng mentioned that this incident involved more than a thousand demonstrators. The police analyzed online clips and found 14 people involved. If new evidence is discovered or discovered later, the police may continue to arrest and prosecute.

title: Who is behind Hong Kong protests?

translation:
According to @globaltimes, Hong Kong police reported that radical and violent demonstrators occupied Harcourt Road in Admiralty, damaged the Legislative Council building, and repeatedly threw petrol bombs, corrosive liquids and bricks. The police used minimum force, including colored water and tear gas, to disperse the demonstrators after repeatedly warning them to stop violating the law.
The Global Times previously reported that on the afternoon of August 31, although the police had issued a notice of objection to the demonstration, a large number of demonstrators still illegally marched westward from Wan Chai. At around 16:20, the Hong Kong police issued another warning.

At about 16:30 in the afternoon, the reporter saw on Des Voeux Road West in Sheung Wan near the Central Liaison Office in Sai Ying Pun, Hong Kong Island. Most of the street shops were closed and there were few pedestrians on the road. Citizens were obviously very worried about violence caused by illegal demonstrations. . The Sai Ying Pun area is a famous seafood market on Hong Kong Island. Many residents come to buy seafood on weekdays and weekends. Today, reporters saw almost no people here.
At around 17:40 in the afternoon, some "demonstrators" set fire in front of the water horse formation deployed by the Hong Kong police at the intersection of Harcourt Road and Tim Wah Road in Admiralty, Hong Kong. The police water cannon truck was immediately dispatched to put out the fire. Subsequently, the illegal demonstrators continued to provoke, and the police once again used water cannon trucks and sprayed colored water spray instead.
Hong Kong police previously introduced that "colored water" is actually edible paint, which is non-toxic in itself and can be fired by a "mobile high-pressure liquid spray device" or a backpack tear gas injector. If the paint water is sprayed, it will remain on the surface of the body or clothes. If necessary, the police can use this to identify whether an individual is at the demonstration site.

title: 维修费达6000万！香港警方将拘捕冲击立法会暴徒
translation:
On the 2nd, detectives from the Organized Crime and Triad Investigation Bureau of the Hong Kong Police searched for evidence inside and outside the Legislative Council Building and collected a large amount of evidence. The police currently have evidence against at least 10 people and will arrest them as soon as possible.
According to reports, the Organized Crime and Triad Investigation Bureau sent a total of about 30 detectives to the Legislative Council Building, Tim Mei Road and the Legislative Council Demonstration Area on the morning of the 2nd to conduct investigations with the Forensic Bureau and Government Chemist personnel. Investigators used 3D scanners to produce three-dimensional or plan views, hoping to obtain accurate measurement data.
The police currently have information on at least 10 people involved in violent crimes. They are suspected of online bullying, attacking various government departments and besieging the police headquarters. The police will carry out continuous arrest operations in the near future. On the 1st, the police arrested 9 people involved in different crimes, including a 35-year-old man surnamed Liu who was involved in transporting supplies.
On the 3rd, Hong Kong's "Bus Daily" quoted a number of legal professionals as saying that the demonstrators who stormed the Legislative Council building had committed multiple criminal offences.
Hong Kong lawyer Luk Wei-hsiung believes that the actions of the demonstrators on the evening of the 1st violated multiple crimes. First of all, those who initially assembled outside the Legislative Council and used tools to break the glass and doors can be charged with illegal assembly and sentenced to up to five years in prison. They also He can be charged with rioting and criminal damage, both of which carry a maximum penalty of ten years in prison.
After entering the Legislative Council building, Lu Weixiong believed that those who vandalized the Legislative Council should add Article 20 of the Public Security Ordinance "rioters demolish buildings and other acts" and Article 21 "rioters destroy buildings, machinery, etc." , Article 23 "Forcible entry" and Article 24 "Forcible occupation of premises". The first two crimes carry a maximum sentence of fourteen years and ten years respectively, while the last two crimes carry a maximum sentence of two years.
Hong Kong lawyer Shi Shuming added that some demonstrators spray-blackened the SAR emblem in the Council Chamber. He said that relevant persons may violate the "Regional Flag and Regional Emblem Ordinance". Anyone can openly and deliberately burn, destroy, scribble, defile, trample, etc. Anyone who insults the regional flag or emblem in such a manner may be punished with a maximum penalty of three years in prison and a fine of NT$50,000.

translation:
Hong Kong public opinion calls for ban
Article 29 of the Hong Kong National Security Law states that “directly or indirectly accepting the instigation, control, funding or other forms of support from foreign or overseas institutions, organizations, personnel, and using various illegal means to cause Hong Kong SAR residents to express their disapproval of the central government or the SAR government. hatred and may cause serious consequences, it is a crime of colluding with foreign countries or external forces to endanger national security." Some analysts said that if the Democratic Front accepts donations from unknown sources, law enforcement agencies can prompt or notify the relevant banks to freeze their accounts. It can be seen from this that groups such as the Civic Party have jumped ship. Not only because the Democratic Front has not been registered, but also because they are worried that law enforcement agencies will be implicated when they investigate the source of funds of the Democratic Front. DAB Legislative Council member Ge Peifan said that most of the demonstrations initiated by the "Democratic Front" eventually turned into riots of beating, smashing, and burning, which raised doubts about the involvement of foreign forces behind the scenes; now, many "speculation-seeking" parties are completely in conflict with the "Democratic Front" The cutting of seats further reflects that the incident is unusual and that relevant departments should investigate as quickly as possible while ensuring national security. Vice Chairman of the New Democratic Party and barrister Yung Hoi-en said that this incident reflects the success of Hong Kong’s national security law in dismantling the forces of chaos in Hong Kong. After the implementation of the National Security Law in Hong Kong, the "speculators" realized that staying in the Democratic Front would have no good results and that the past actions of the Democratic Front may be illegal, so they withdrew one after another. This has further raised questions about their alleged collusion with foreign countries to endanger the country. security, and even received funding from the "anti-China chaos in Hong Kong" forces. The Security Bureau and the National Security Division of the Police should further investigate. Some Hong Kong media said on the 13th that Russian media disclosed in July 2019 that the "Hong Kong Society of Human Resources Management", "Hong Kong Workers' Union" and "Hong Kong Journalists Association" had cooperated with NED and obtained funds. The above-mentioned organizations were all "Floem Democratic" "member. The SAR government is launching an investigation. If it is confirmed that the Democratic Front has received foreign funding, the organization should be banned.

title: 香港警方反对7月1日集会游行：增加市民染疫风险
translation:

According to reports, due to the impact of the new coronavirus epidemic, the Hong Kong SAR government has extended the "ban on gatherings" until July 2, restricting gatherings of more than 50 people. The notice of objection issued by the Hong Kong Police yesterday (26th) also pointed out that taking into account factors such as the epidemic and the "ban on gatherings", it is believed that holding public gatherings or processions will increase the risk of citizens contracting the epidemic and pose a threat to the lives and health of all citizens. Serious threats, endangering public safety and affecting the rights of others.
In addition, the police mentioned in the notice of objection that violent incidents occurred during the parade on July 1 last year, as well as at many public gatherings or parades from May to June this year, and the application for this parade was very close to being approved. Buildings at high risk of conflict and violence.
After the police issued the notice of objection, the applicant immediately lodged an appeal. The Public Meetings and Processions Appeal Committee held a hearing this morning (27th) and ultimately decided to uphold its objection to the holding of the above two processions and rallies on the grounds that the processions were contrary to public safety, order and security.

社评：搞“七一大游行”不符合香港利益
translation:
The so-called "political reform referendum" initiated by Hong Kong's "Occupy Central" activists was announced yesterday, with organizers claiming that "more than 780,000 people" participated in the vote. This figure has been widely questioned, with many saying they were able to vote electronically repeatedly through various means. Tomorrow is July 1, and the opposition calls on Hong Kong citizens who have voted to participate in the "July 1" demonstrations to continue to put pressure on the central government.

Such demonstrations are legal in Hong Kong, but from holding a "referendum" to organizing the "July 1 Parade" to planning the large-scale "Occupy Central" action, all of this has continued to portray and accumulate the "political power" of the radical opposition. The image of "antagonist" pushes the diversity of Hong Kong society in the direction of division, which is not in the interest of the vast majority of Hong Kong people.

The Hong Kong opposition is supposed to be an opposition within the Special Administrative Region. The entire political operation mechanism of Hong Kong is determined by the Basic Law and supervised by the central government. However, the radical forces in the Hong Kong opposition are now targeting the central government and the Basic Law. From the perspective of the national constitution, this is a serious misalignment.

The white paper issued by the central government not long ago clearly requires that the candidate for chief executive must be selected from people who "patriotize and love Hong Kong." The radical opposition rejected this condition, which implicitly requires that people who are hostile to the central government can also run for election. If the central government makes concessions to them, Hong Kong's future will face huge uncertainty.

The radical opposition in Hong Kong probably knows that their request is impossible to achieve, and they seem to be treating the current series of actions as a mobilization process for the "opposition" of Hong Kong society. Officials and scholars in Hong Kong and the Mainland have repeatedly called for the need to avoid confrontation between Mainland society and Hong Kong society. In fact, there is no organizational force in the Mainland to promote confrontation with Hong Kong society. When Mainland public opinion rebounds against the radical opposition in Hong Kong, it also All have this consciousness.

However, Hong Kong's radical opposition seems to be trying every possible means to build a "chariot" to trick as many Hong Kong citizens into boarding this vehicle. Its target is the central government and the general public across the country. We want to say to the citizens of Hong Kong, don’t get on this “chariot”, don’t be kidnapped by the radical opposition, and use Hong Kong’s prosperity and your well-being as bargaining chips for them.

七一还想闹事，港警发反对通知书
translation:
According to Hong Kong's "Wen Wei Po", Eastern District Councilor Xu Zijian and others who participated in the "primary election" of the speculators wanted to increase their political capital. On the 25th, they threatened to hold demonstrations on the 28th of this month and the 1st of next month.
However, the embarrassing thing is that the only onlookers that day were the media, with almost no pedestrians stopping to support, and the scene was very deserted. Even Xu Zijian himself admitted that currently there are only more than 30 district councilors who are pro-speculators supporting the demonstration, accounting for less than 10% of the total district council members who are pro-speculators.
The Hong Kong police have currently issued a "notice of objection" to the above-mentioned parade, and responded to Xu Zijian on the 26th, saying that it is prohibited to hold rallies and parades on Hong Kong Island this Sunday and July 1.
The police said that taking into account factors such as the epidemic and the "gathering restriction order", the police believe that public gatherings and parades are high-risk activities where large numbers of people gather.
The letter states that the COVID-19 response level in Hong Kong is the highest level of "emergency". The relevant public gatherings and processions are not exempted from the "Restriction on Gathering Order" group gatherings. Holding or participating in rallies and processions is illegal and will disrupt public order. . The police have reason to believe that holding relevant activities will increase the risk of virus infection among participants and other citizens, and will pose a major threat to the lives and health of all citizens.
The police also stated that given that the social atmosphere has remained unstable recently, after careful assessment, there is reason to believe that some participants in this rally and procession may deviate from the original route and violently damage nearby high-risk buildings, including MTR stations, Police Headquarters and Government Headquarters. The police said that any person who knowingly participates in an unauthorized assembly without reasonable excuse commits an offence.

title: 维修费达6000万！香港警方将拘捕冲击立法会暴徒
translation:

It is estimated that the maintenance cost of the building is expected to be HK$60 million (approximately RMB 52.98 million), and the maintenance time will be more than three months, and it will not be put into use until October this year.
In addition, Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor also stated that demonstrators have been confronting the police since the morning of the 1st, blocking roads, using unknown liquids and toxic chemical powders to attack the police, and storming the Legislative Council building in an extremely violent manner.
In response, Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor stated in the early morning of the 2nd that these violent acts have seriously affected the core values ​​of Hong Kong's rule of law and must be strongly condemned. The Hong Kong government will "pursue to the end" any illegal behavior.
Li Ka-chiu, Secretary for Security of the Hong Kong SAR Government, and Lo Wai-chung, Commissioner of Police of the Hong Kong SAR Government, stated that the actions of the violent attackers were seriously illegal and posed a great threat to the public. The police condemn this series of acts of disregard of law and order in the strongest possible terms, and will conduct a comprehensive investigation and follow up seriously.
Chairman of the Hong Kong Legislative Council Leung Kwan-yin said that no matter what political opinions, violence should never be used to resolve the issue.

China News Service, November 19. According to the website of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government, Hong Kong "Occupy Action" demonstrators attacked the Hong Kong Legislative Council building in the early morning of the 19th, causing damage to many parts of the building. Police have arrested six people and strongly condemned acts that disrupted public order. 

Hong Kong government sources said that the incident occurred at 1 a.m., and demonstrators used iron horses (obstacles) and bricks to violently attack the building many times. Many glass doors in the building were shattered and brick walls were pried off. The police arrived at the scene to assist at the request of the Legislative Council.

The demonstrators also attempted to prevent the police from enforcing the law. The demonstrators ignored the advice and warnings, so the police used minimum force to stop the attack, including using pepper spray to prevent the demonstrators from continuing to attack and defend themselves against attacks. Three police officers were injured in the incident. 

The police reiterated that Hong Kong society agrees that demands should be expressed in a rational and peaceful manner and that behaviors that undermine public order and public safety will never be tolerated.

The Special Administrative Region Government strongly condemned the actions of thugs who stormed the Legislative Council building on the 19th, emphasizing that citizens must abide by the law when expressing their opinions or demands and will never tolerate violence. 

As a result, the Public Works Subcommittee meeting and the Legislative Council meeting originally scheduled to be held on the morning of the 19th were forced to be rescheduled, and the operations of the Parliament were further delayed.

Yuen Kwok-keung, the Secretary for Justice of the SAR Government, emphasized that the police and the Department of Justice will handle matters in accordance with laws and established procedures. He reiterated that illegal or unlawful acts will not be allowed to undermine the rule of law. If there is sufficient evidence, law enforcement will be strictly enforced. He does not want to release the idea that "people who commit illegal acts can get away with it." ” information, which is also the basic requirement and practice of the rule of law.

Yuen Guoqiang said that he believed that the vast majority of Hong Kong people did not want to see violent incidents or express their demands in a violent way, and called on the occupying people or other demonstrators not to express their demands in a violent way.

translation:
For protests such as the "July 1 Parade", adapt to them and don't take them too seriously
Hong Kong held another "July 1st Parade" yesterday. The number of people was said to be more than in previous years, but there is a big gap between the statistics of various parties. The opposition is happy and considers this year's march and the previous "referendum" to be their "victory" by adding pressure on the central government. Two Hong Kong student organizations staged an "Occupy Central" event in advance last night, claiming that they would wait until Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying went to work this morning and demand dialogue with him. Their plan challenged Hong Kong's laws and constituted a test of the Hong Kong government's handling capabilities.

The July 1st March has become a new "protest political tradition" in Hong Kong. Its core organizer is the Hong Kong opposition, but the actual participants and their demands are becoming more and more diverse. "Democracy activists" and gay supporters who have fled from the mainland will use the July 1st parade to show their presence. There are also many people who just express their "dissatisfaction" or just want to join in the fun, treating the parade as a party and carnival to relieve stress and jointly create a grand impression.

The opposition is very concerned about the number of people attending the July 1st demonstrations, and the numbers they publish every time are higher than the actual statistics of the police. When watching the July 1st Parade in Hong Kong from the mainland, you must have a relieved attitude. The number of people marching to a certain extent reflects the sentiment of Hong Kong society, but the relationship between the two is not equal. Public opinion in Hong Kong is complex, and rational fundamentals have always existed. The opposition wants to influence policy formulation through street actions, which should never be encouraged.

In the coming period, the Hong Kong opposition will intensify various protests and even "disobedience" activities to strive for the central government to make concessions that break through the Basic Law around Hong Kong's political reform. It is difficult for ordinary citizens in Hong Kong to fully understand the Basic Law. The opposition's use of "Hong Kong democracy is under threat" to scare everyone can cater to the concerns of many ordinary people, thereby drawing them into protests and building momentum against the central government.

In court yesterday, except for Bi Huifen and Pan Haochao who had to continue to repay due to other cases, eight of the other defendants who were granted bail applied to change one of the bail conditions from reporting to the police station once a week to once every two weeks. The prosecution objected, but the judge ultimately approved the defendant's application. In addition, the prosecution applied to consolidate the cases that were originally divided into five cases. One of the defendants reserved the right to object, so the judge adjourned the case to October 16 for another hearing at the West Kowloon Magistrates' Courts.
The 12 defendants were charged with the crime of entering or remaining in the Legislative Council Chamber, which refers to violating the "Legislative Council (Powers and Privileges) Ordinance" when they entered the Legislative Council Chamber with other unknown persons on the evening of July 1 last year. "Administrative instructions issued by "Failure to comply with order or instructions issued by members of the Legislative Council to maintain order." As for the riot charges they were charged with, it was alleged that they participated in a riot with other unknown persons at the Legislative Council Complex on the same day and night.
According to reports, 12 people including Liu Yingkuang, who advocated "soliciting speculation" and incited violence, and Sun Xiaolan, former president of the Hong Kong Students' Union, were originally charged with entering or staying in the conference hall. Later, they were charged with an additional charge at the Eastern District Magistrates' Court. Riot crime.
In addition, one of the defendants, "Zhan Wang painter" Poon Ho-chiu, was also charged with one more crime of rioting, alleging that he participated in a riot at the Legislative Council Building on the same afternoon, illegally assembled at the Main Foreign Affairs Office of Tim Mei Road in Admiralty, and illegally damaged property belonging to the Hong Kong government. translation:
On November 18, the 52nd day of Hong Kong's illegal "Occupy Movement", many bailiffs in Hong Kong formally launched an operation to clear obstacles outside the CITIC Building in Admiralty in the morning. The staff wearing gloves cut open the iron horses with iron pliers. tape between them and removed the iron horses one by one. 
    China News Service, November 19. According to the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government website, the Hong Kong police strongly condemned the "Occupy Action" demonstrators who stormed the Hong Kong Legislative Council building and disrupted public order in the early morning of the 19th. During the incident, the police arrested four men aged 18 to 24 on suspicion of criminal damage and assaulting police officers. Three male police officers were injured and sent to hospital for treatment.

    At around 1 a.m. this morning, demonstrators stormed the Legislative Council building, causing damage to many parts of the building. The police arrived at the scene to provide assistance at the request of the Legislative Council. The demonstrators repeatedly attacked the police lines. After persuasion and warnings failed, the police took measures, including the use of pepper spray, to prevent the demonstrators from continuing to attack and to defend against attacks.

    The Hong Kong police strongly condemn the actions of these demonstrators that disrupt public order. The police appealed to demonstrators at the scene to follow the instructions of police officers and leave the scene peacefully and orderly. The police reiterated that Hong Kong society agrees to express demands in a rational and peaceful manner, and the police will never tolerate behavior that undermines public order and public safety.

    With the assistance of court bailiffs and the police, the Hong Kong High Court again issued an injunction on the CITIC Building in Admiralty and began to implement it on the 18th. The court authorized the police to arrest, if necessary, those who obstructed bailiffs from carrying out their duties. Enforcing a court injunction is not always smooth sailing.

    The radical student organization "Students", the Hong Kong Federation of Students, opposition members of the SAR Legislative Council, and members of radical organizations stood in front of the iron fence and continued to make noises. They even besieged the bailiff and prevented the staff from clearing the roadblock. Members of the Federation of Students even asked the bailiff to explain the injunction and prove how the roadblock blocked traffic.

    On the 18th, despite the presence of bailiffs to assist, the clearing of roadblocks continued intermittently. After a morning of hustle and bustle, part of the road outside CITIC Tower was reopened to traffic at about 2 p.m.

    On November 18, the 52nd day of Hong Kong's illegal "Occupy Movement", many bailiffs in Hong Kong formally launched an operation to clear obstacles outside the CITIC Building in Admiralty in the morning. The staff wearing gloves cut open the iron horses with iron pliers. They removed the tape between them and moved the iron horses one by one without encountering any obstacles. 

    On November 18, Hong Kong bailiffs went to the entrance and exit of the CITIC Building in Admiralty to enforce the injunction order in the morning. Some illegal occupiers first went outside the CITIC Building and removed some obstacles.

title: 涉嫌暴力冲击香港立法会，12人已被警方拘捕！
translation:
Police have arrested 12 people
A "Global Times" reporter saw on the 3rd that the internal facilities of the Hong Kong Legislative Council were severely damaged, extreme words were sprayed on the walls and elevators, documents in the archives were scattered all over the floor, and even members' personal lockers were pried open. A staff member of the Legislative Council told reporters that everyone should see with their own eyes the evidence of the violent acts of extreme radicals. On the second floor, the building's CCTV was destroyed, suspected to be by violent demonstrators to avoid being photographed. The wall was cut open and the network cables were cut in a very "professional" manner. The above-mentioned Legislative Council staff member said that it is difficult to believe that this kind of method was done by ordinary students. Former Hong Kong Chief Executive and Vice Chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, Tung Chee-hwa, questioned on the 3rd that the attack on the Legislative Council may involve a behind-the-scenes organization, hoping that it can be traced.
When a "Global Times" reporter interviewed the Legislative Council on the 3rd, Hong Kong police were cleaning up debris and crime tools left by violent demonstrators, including iron bars, scaffolding, floor tiles and umbrellas dismantled from nearby construction sites. Legislative Council staff told reporters that the police evidence collection work has been completed.
The violent acts of extreme radicals have aroused the anger of Hong Kong citizens. Many people launched a "city-wide arrest order to protect the harbor" through online discussion forums and social media, calling for the reporting of demonstrators suspected of participating in illegal actions. A reporter from the Global Times saw the article titled "All People Unite, Wanted Thugs" saying that on the evening of the 1st, someone directed the rioters through an online private chat group to cut off wires and steal computer information.
Hong Kong's Hong Kong Economic Journal published an editorial on the 3rd saying that the Legislative Council was broken into and occupied for about three hours. There is no need to deny the violence, it is justifiable to condemn it, and it is understandable to impose sanctions in accordance with the law. Hong Kong's "Sing Tao Daily" reported that Legislative Council member Leung Mei-fun and some members of the legal profession initiated a joint signature, with more than 130 participants. They described July 1 this year as "the darkest day in the 176-year history of the Legislative Council." They condemned the attack, destruction and insult on the Legislative Council that day, which completely exceeded the bottom line of a society governed by the rule of law. They stressed that expressing opinions must not go beyond the law and the Basic Law. 》The bottom line cannot shake the foundation of "one country, two systems".
The four major chambers of commerce, including the Chinese General Chamber of Commerce of Hong Kong, the Chinese Manufacturers' Federation of Hong Kong, the Federation of Hong Kong Industries and the Chinese Import and Export Chamber of Commerce of Hong Kong, issued the strongest condemnation on the 3rd for the violent actions that attacked the Legislative Council, expressing their full support for the SAR government and the police to take action in accordance with the law as soon as possible. Restoring social order and public tranquility, and pursuing responsibilities in accordance with the law. According to a report by Radio Television Hong Kong on the evening of the 3rd, in connection with the violent attack on the Legislative Council, the police have arrested 11 men and 1 woman on suspicion of possession of offensive weapons, assaulting police officers and other crimes.

title: 香港2019年“9·29冲突”11人暴动罪成，9人被判监禁，2人判入教导所

Hong Kong East Network and Orange News reported that 9 of the 11 people were each sentenced to three and a half years in prison in the Hong Kong District Court today (9th). The other two people, who were 18 and 16 years old at the time of the incident, were sentenced to education. Place.​
According to reports, on September 29, 2019, someone launched a demonstration and subsequently surrounded the Hong Kong SAR Government Headquarters in Admiralty. Some people threw petrol bombs and debris. The 11 men and women involved had previously denied the charges and were found guilty of rioting after trial. established.
According to reports, Hong Kong District Court Judge Yiu Xunzhi said on the 9th that there were many people involved in this case and the level of violence was high. Some people threw petrol bombs and damaged the water horse of the political headquarters. At the same time, arson and criminal damage occurred, causing certain property losses, and the riot continued After a certain period of time, if the consequences were not for the police to intervene and the consequences would be more serious, the court would have to impose deterrent sentences. After consideration, 9 of them were sentenced to 3 and a half years in prison, and the remaining 2 were sentenced to a training center.

translation:
After the handover, general education became a compulsory subject for Hong Kong's college entrance examination, but it has become a platform for Hong Kong's unscrupulous teachers to misguide young students.
I flipped through some general education textbooks, and what I suddenly saw were general education textbooks written by some teachers that attacked "one country, two systems", beautified the illegal "Occupy Central", intensified conflicts between Hong Kong and the mainland, and vilified and stigmatized the mainland... It has become a de facto political propaganda and is used to incite students to participate in radical illegal actions.
The deficiencies and distortions in Chinese history education also have far-reaching consequences. Since 2000, Chinese history has been no longer a compulsory subject in Hong Kong schools for a long time. Many Hong Kong young people have grown up in a curriculum framework that blurs their historical roots and forgets about historical changes.
"Some teachers who grew up in the British Hong Kong era have never experienced patriotic education or Chinese history education, and have a superficial understanding of history and national conditions, and are even full of negative cognitions and prejudices. Their elaboration of history and guidance to students have contributed to Young people are dissatisfied with the status quo," said Mu Jiajun, a teacher at Pei Qiao Middle School in Hong Kong.
Hong Kong political commentator Qu Yingyan pointed out that in Hong Kong junior high school textbooks, "the 'national hatred' part about the Nanjing Massacre only has 75 words, but the 'family hatred' part about the Great Leap Forward and the 'Cultural Revolution' takes 18 pages. So everyone You will understand why young people in Hong Kong don’t blush when they hold the British and American flags.”

Lee Ka-chiu pointed out that the court determined that the crime of conspiracy to subvert state power was committed in this case, aiming to undermine, destroy or overthrow the current political system and structure of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region established by the Basic Law and the "One Country, Two Systems" policy.
Li Jiachao emphasized that the SAR has the responsibility to safeguard national security and will resolutely crack down on behaviors and activities that endanger national security. This is a despicable plot that blatantly tramples on the rule of law, and the SAR government condemns it in the strongest possible terms.

translation:
Amnesty International, which has repeatedly smeared China, decided to withdraw from Hong Kong
Amnesty International, which often interferes in the internal affairs of other countries in the name of "human rights," claims that it will be impossible for human rights organizations to operate freely in Hong Kong after the implementation of Hong Kong's national security law, and it will close its two offices in Hong Kong before the end of this year. Chief Executive Carrie Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor said when meeting reporters before attending the Executive Council today (26th) that different organizations and people have left Hong Kong on the grounds that Hong Kong has implemented the Hong Kong National Security Law, but no one can prove that this is the real reason.
Lam Cheng Yuet-ngor said that citizens’ freedom of speech and assembly are protected by the Basic Law, and Hong Kong’s National Security Law also has provisions to protect human rights. Unless any organization uses Hong Kong to engage in activities that endanger national security, there is no need to worry if it operates legitimately and legally.
Carrie Lam also listed actual data to refute the organization's fallacies. She said that the number of mainland and overseas companies setting up offices in Hong Kong rose instead of falling, breaking a record to more than 9,000. In addition, some international and regional legal institutions have also set up offices in Hong Kong, reflecting that Hong Kong’s national security law does not deter people from engaging in legitimate activities.

香港之乱丨侮辱国旗、冲击立法会……暴力示威让东方之珠蒙尘
translation:
On July 21, 2019, radicals surrounded and attacked the Liaison Office of the Central People’s Government in Hong Kong. They threw eggs and black paint bombs at the national emblem, and wrote words that insulted the dignity of the country and nation.

On August 3, 2019, at the Star Ferry Pier in Tsim Sha Tsui, several masked black-clad extreme radicals tore down the national flag from the flagpole and threw it into the sea. At the same time, a flag with the slogan "Hong Kong Independence" was raised.

On August 5, 2019, in Tsim Sha Tsui, the national flag was once again torn down and trampled on.

Hong Kong citizens: It’s like the Eight-Nation Allied Forces have entered, and our national flag looks like it’s been trampled by horses. If you don't respect me, don't insult me. You are insulting the entire nation, so (I) am angry.
British expert Adam Gary: You can imagine what it would be like if a mob broke into the U.S. Congress, insulted the U.S. national emblem, and raised the flag of another country. This illegal behavior is very wrong.

The flag that insults one's own country is actually the flag of colonial Hong Kong, or even the flag of the British and American countries.

Polish media person Rafael Tomanski: To be honest, I don’t understand why these people are waving the British flag, or the British colonial flag. The British colonists would not tolerate demonstrations. The police at that time would use tear gas and other methods to end the demonstrations as quickly as possible.

Famous British scholar Martin Jacques: Do they really want to go back to the 156 years when the British colonized Hong Kong? Are they praising democracy? Sorry, in the 156 years since the British colonized Hong Kong, they have never implemented any form of universal suffrage in Hong Kong, not even a shadow of it.

Hong Kong citizens: You are Chinese, you are Hong Kongers, you must protect this place, and you cannot make this place such a mess.

最新铁证！美国在香港搞“政治731”实验，上千大学生成“小白鼠”
translation:
Zhi Zhenfeng, a researcher at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, told reporters that this paper provides a very authoritative confirmation. Because an academic paper has strict requirements on method and data sources and must undergo anonymous review, the accuracy of the facts disclosed in this academic paper is no less accurate than a news report, or even more accurate than a news report.
From this, we can see how the West is deeply involved in social movements in other countries and regions and provokes social unrest in other countries. In the form of an academic paper, the author describes the United States' instigation, instigation, and participation in organizing social movements in other countries and regions. A more accurate description. Three points can be seen:
First, the violent social movements in Hong Kong and many other places have foreign masterminds.
Second, the United States and the West are organized, premeditated, methodological, funded, and involved in inciting color revolution social violence in other places.
Third, we can see that the distorted values ​​and morals of the United States and the West actually regard inciting riots in other countries as a glorious mission, and do so openly and openly, to the point of cognitive confusion, obsession, and pride instead of shame.
Lu Xiang, a researcher at the Institute of American Studies of the Academy of Social Sciences, told reporters that similar papers would not be allowed to be published if they were used for domestic political research in the United States. Because this article involves some data on society as a whole, it falls under the category of national security and should be subject to strict laws and regulations.
Obviously, there will be various dissatisfactions in any society, but no country will allow such dissatisfaction to turn into political riots. Such a paper, to put it bluntly, provides a social psychological basis for organizing political protests in disguise.
The publication of such articles shows that the United States only cares about its own stability, completely ignores the stability of other countries and regions, and even hopes that some target countries will be unstable. The United States has a long tradition of engaging in "color revolutions" abroad, and has a complete set of methods to guide them. Under the guidance of this method, various sporadic dissatisfactions in society can easily aggregate into political and thematic dissatisfaction. Lu Xiang calls it "horizontal" mobilization, which gathers dissatisfaction from all corners under one banner.
On the other hand, this paper also reflects that before the introduction of the Hong Kong National Security Law, Hong Kong society had a serious lack of security for a long period of time. However, now is not the time to talk about accountability, but to quickly close the loopholes one by one.
