translation:
Hong Kong media pointed out that on July 1, Chen Haohuan, Xu Zijian, Wu Zhiwei, Zhu Kaidi, Liang Guoxiong and Tang Shili organized and led a parade in the area from To Lao Chi Road to Hennessy Road in Wan Chai to conduct an unauthorized assembly. After in-depth investigation and consultation with the Department of Justice for legal advice, the Criminal Division of the Hong Kong Island Region decided to take arrest action this morning and arrested 8 men ranging in age from 24 to 64 years old in multiple districts across Hong Kong.
It is reported that among the eight people involved in the case, Chen Haohuan and Hu Zhiwei were charged with three counts of inciting others, holding or organizing, and participating in unauthorized assemblies; Liang Guoxiong, Zhu Kaidi, and Deng Shili were charged with holding or organizing, and participating in unauthorized assemblies. Two counts of approving an assembly; Zeng Jiancheng, Chen Rongtai and Xu Zijian were charged with inciting others to participate in an unauthorized assembly.
The report pointed out that this year, on the first July 1st Handover Day after the implementation of the National Security Law in Hong Kong, the opposition organization "Democratic Front" and other groups launched a march on Hong Kong Island on that day. Although the police refused to issue a "notice of no objection", there were still people in Causeway Bay and Hong Kong that day. A large number of violent demonstrators appeared in Wan Chai area, blocking roads with debris, setting fires and damaging shops. Some people waved "Hong Kong independence" flags and American and British flags on the streets, and shouted slogans opposing Hong Kong's national security law and "Hong Kong independence". The police sprayed pepper spray, fired tear gas and fired water cannons to disperse the demonstrators, and arrested 370 people.

冲击立法会罪名成立，“港独”分子梁颂恒上诉被驳即时入狱
translation:
In 2016, "Hong Kong independence" activist Leung Chung-hang was dissatisfied with his disqualification as a member. He stormed the Legislative Council with Yau Wai-chen and three other people. He was charged with participating in illegal assembly and was sentenced to four weeks in prison in 2018. He was later released on bail pending appeal.
According to Hong Kong's "Eastern Net" news, today (September 2), the Hong Kong High Court rejected Liang Songheng's appeal, and he must be imprisoned immediately to serve his sentence. The judge believed that the conviction was not unsafe and the sentence was not obviously excessive, so he dismissed his appeal application.
In 2016, then-Legislative Council members Leung Chung-hang and Yau Wai-chen displayed "Hong Kong Independence" slogans and altered their oaths while taking the oath, and were ruled to have lost their qualifications as members. The two are both members of the "Youth New Deal", a "Hong Kong independence" organization.
On November 2 of the same year, he, together with You Huizhen and three assistants, forced their way into the Legislative Council conference room. Leung Chung-hang and Yau Wai-ching were charged with using "extreme force" to enter the Legislative Council conference room on the day of the incident, and were involved in the crime of participating in an illegal assembly.
In May 2018, Hong Kong's Kowloon City Magistrates' Court convicted Leung Chung-hang and sentenced him to four weeks in prison. Subsequently, Liang Songheng was granted bail and appealed to the Hong Kong High Court, requesting to overturn the conviction and apply for a commutation of sentence. In June this year, the Court of First Instance of the Hong Kong High Court opened a hearing on the case.
On September 2, the court officially rejected Liang Songheng’s appeal application, and he was therefore required to serve his sentence in prison immediately. Judge Chan Ka-Shing of the Court of First Instance believed that the conviction by the Kowloon City Magistrates' Court was not unsafe and the sentence was not obviously excessive, so he dismissed his appeal application.
Barrister Kenneth Kwok, who represents Leung Chung-heng, said he plans to appeal to the Court of Final Appeal.
It is worth mentioning that when Leung Chung-hang and Yau Wai-chen were ruled to have lost their membership qualifications in 2016, they had only been in office for 12 days, but they had already received one month's parliamentary salary of about HK$90,000 each, and more than HK$830,000 in advance operating funds.
The Administrative Committee of the Hong Kong Legislative Council (AC) filed with the District Court in 2017 and 2018 to recover the above-mentioned amounts from the two people. In May 2020, the Hong Kong court ruled that the two must return a total of approximately NT$1.86 million in salary and advances to the ACAC, and pay the ACAC’s legal fees.
You Huizhen's proposal to repay in installments was accepted. She will repay HK$25,000 per month in 48 installments. Liang Songheng still ignored it. On August 18, the Administration Commission filed a petition with the Hong Kong High Court to make Leung Chung Hang bankrupt. "Eastern Net" quoted the Legislative Council Secretariat as saying that this is the first time that the ACCM has submitted a bankruptcy petition to an individual.

translation:
The numbers are false and there is a black hand behind it.

The People's Daily stated that the "Democratic Front", which launched the "July 1" march in Hong Kong, claimed that the number of people marching this year was more than five times that announced by the police. This shows that the "Democratic Front" is crazy about counting (big numbers). The newspaper cited an article by Wen Pingli published by Hong Kong's Wen Wei Po and pointed out that in fact, the police used a scientific and rigorous statistical method to count the number of people in the march, which was well-founded. The opposition insists that this is nothing more than a "self-fulfilling lie", telling and directing its own lies. Who else would believe such numbers?

Follow-up: More than 500 demonstrators in Hong Kong have been released

According to the People's Daily, the Hong Kong police have released more than 500 arrested demonstrators. The police issued warning notices to 486 people who participated in the "July 1 Parade", and 25 others were granted bail pending investigation and reported to the police from late July to early August. The police said that three arrested men aged 18 to 68 were found with screwdrivers, knives or folding knives on their bodies and were arrested on suspicion of "possession of offensive weapons", while another 21-year-old woman was arrested on suspicion of "assaulting a police officer" .

香港警方再拘4人 冲击立法会暴力分子大起底
translation:
The evil consequences caused by the connivance of the pan-people

Hong Kong public opinion analysis believes that although the Federation of Students and others severely condemned the "hot-blooded citizens" and caused the "Occupy Movement" to split, the reason was that they believed that the "hot-blooded citizens" were causing chaos and ruining the opposition's major events. According to the opposition's wishful thinking, it was originally planned to arrange for extreme radical groups such as "Hot-Blooded Citizens" to establish themselves in Mong Kok and prepare to use violent means to clear the area. The "occupied area" in Admiralty needs to maintain the so-called "peaceful and non-violent" image in order to encourage the people and students to "occupy" it for a long time. The actions of the "passionate citizens" essentially tore off the opposition's veil. "Oriental Daily" stated that the so-called "Peaceful Occupy Central" slogan has gone bankrupt. "Ta Kung Pao" stated that although some in the opposition play bad-face and some play white-face, no matter how it is covered up and no matter what cuts are made in response to the backlash of public opinion, "violence is violence and cannot be separated from it."

The "Sing Tao Daily" editorial stated that the increasingly violent actions of radicals were due to the early connivance of the pan-democrats. At the same time, the "Occupy Operation" created an environment that facilitated radical actions. Pan-democrats and student organizations simply cannot control this group of people. As long as the "occupation" continues, they will be provided with opportunities to cause trouble.

title: The rule of law must prevail in HKSAR

香港“35+”非法初选案45人罪成，李家超发声
translation:
According to reports from Hong Kong media such as Dakong Wenhui.com and Sing Tao Daily, 47 people were charged with "conspiracy to subvert state power" for allegedly organizing and participating in the "35+ illegal primary elections" in Hong Kong, and a total of 45 people were convicted. Thirty-one of the defendants pleaded guilty before trial and were awaiting sentencing. On May 30, 14 of the remaining 16 people who did not plead guilty were found guilty.
According to reports, 47 defendants suspected of organizing and participating in the "35+ illegal primary election case" conspired to conspire in the 2020 Legislative Council election. After gaining more than half of the seats in the Legislative Council, they planned to veto the financial plan proposed by the SAR government indiscriminately, forcing Hong Kong to The chief executive dissolved the Legislative Council and resigned, and was jointly charged with "conspiracy to subvert state power." Among them, 31 people, including the Hong Kong chaos leader Benny Tai, pleaded guilty before trial and awaited sentencing. The remaining 16 people who did not plead guilty were tried for 118 days.
On May 30, the West Kowloon Magistrates' Court ruled that Wu Zhengheng, Zheng Dahong, Yang Xueying, Peng Zhuoqi, He Qiming, Huang Biyun, Shi Delai, He Guilan, Chen Zhiquan, Zou Jiacheng, Lam Zhuoting, Leung Kwok-hung, Ke Yiolin and Yu Huiming were found guilty. Due to insufficient evidence, Liu Weicong and Li Yuxin were found not guilty. The Hong Kong Department of Justice immediately appealed against the two men's acquittal.
According to Article 22 of the Hong Kong National Security Law, once the defendant is convicted, if he is a ringleader or if the crime is serious, he shall be sentenced to life imprisonment or a fixed-term imprisonment of not less than 10 years; active participants shall be sentenced to a fixed-term imprisonment of not less than 3 years but not more than 10 years; other participants shall be sentenced to a fixed-term imprisonment of not less than 3 years but not more than 10 years. Fixed-term imprisonment of not more than 3 years, criminal detention or public surveillance.

translation:
Wan Dehao pointed out that the impact incident in this case damaged the Legislative Council's property, and the maintenance cost amounted to NT$420,000. A security guard was injured when he stopped the demonstrators from moving the iron horses, and suffered a broken toe. The environment was dangerous and it was just "good luck" that no one died or that few people were injured. He emphasized that the defendants in this case showed no sincere remorse. After being convicted in the original trial, they admitted to the magistrate that they would not regret what they had done. Some of the defendants even appealed against their convictions. The Department of Justice believes that immediate imprisonment is the only appropriate sentence for each defendant, and the maximum sentence for illegal assembly under summary procedure is three years. He believed the court should consider the sentence at the "upper middle end" of the maximum possible sentence.

The case continued this morning. After both sides made their arguments, the judge finally ruled: Based on the degree of violence in the case and everyone's attitude, the social service order was obviously too light. Starting from 15 months' imprisonment, each defendant was sentenced to 8 to 13 months in prison. moon. The 13 defendants in this case are Liang Xiaoyang, Huang Haoming, Liu Guoliang, Liang Yingli, Lin Langyan, Zhu Weicong, He Jiehong, Zhou Huoran, Yan Minhua, Zhao Xiancong, Guo Yaochang, Huang Yuanyuan and Chen Baishan. Except Huang Yuan Yuan, who pleaded guilty, was sentenced to 8 months, the others were sentenced to 13 months. The court also issued an arrest warrant for the absent defendant Zhao Xiancong.
During this morning's court hearing, Zhu Weicong, Zhou Huoran and Chen Baishan did not hire lawyers to represent them. In their speeches, Zhu and Tuesday expressed regret for the excessive behavior and the injured security personnel that day. But at the same time, Zhu Weicong said that he "will not regret it", while Zhou Huoran said that "I did nothing wrong."

Today, Dagong.com also published a comment titled "'Social Service' Is Unreasonable and Reviews the Legal Principles". The article pointed out that this case has set an unprecedented precedent in Hong Kong in terms of violent demonstrations and protests and attacks on public security. Its serious nature and impact are unprecedented. Social service orders are “unprecedented.” Violent attacks can be "socialized", which is unjust; if the Department of Justice's review fails, it is unreasonable.

title: Commentary: Call Hong Kong police who they are: heroes of Hong Kong
香港激进反对派“七一游行”后内讧 成员挑衅互殴
translation:
According to reports from Sing Tao Daily and Ta Kung Pao, more than a hundred people including the "Social Democratic League" marched to Government House without applying for a no-objection notice and clashed with the police. The police once fired pepper spray to disperse the demonstrators. The demonstrators dispersed one after another, and some of them walked to the Court of Final Appeal, but violent clashes broke out with the CUHK Student Union.

The "Social Democratic League" decided to end the march at that time, but some members of the CUHK Student Union came forward to question why they did not block the road. The chairman of the "Social Democratic League" Wu Wenyuan said at the time that they would not stop the other party from blocking the road. Afterwards, Zhou Shufeng suddenly shouted: "You just What are you doing with your feet? You kicked me head first!" Community citizen Lian Chen Dezhang immediately yelled, "You are eating shit! You are so angry, Zhou Shufeng!" Later, members of the CUHK Student Union left the scene.

title: 乱港头目认罪，反华机构要撤出香港∣香港一日
translation:
Former "Democratic Front" convener pleads guilty to participating in illegal demonstrations
Chen Haohuan, a Hong Kong rioter and former convenor of the Hong Kong chaos organization "Democratic Front", was previously accused by the police of participating in an illegal demonstration on Hong Kong Island on September 15, 2019. He was charged with "knowingly participating in an unauthorized assembly". Today (26th) ) pleaded guilty at the Eastern Magistrates' Court.
According to the case, the Hong Kong pro-democracy organization "Democratic Front", which announced its disbandment on August 13 this year, applied to hold a parade in Causeway Bay at 3 pm on September 15 of that year near the Chater Road pedestrian area in Central, but the police opposed it. Chen Haohuan later stated through social networking sites that he would go to Causeway Bay to participate in the rally in his personal capacity, and incited the crowd: "Let's all gather at East Point Road at 2:30 and march to the finish line together," claiming "I have the right to demonstrate" and "No police approval is required." , and said he was ready to be arrested and was not afraid of going to jail. It is worth noting that this does not allow Chen Haohuan to deny it. In several videos played by the prosecution in court, Chen Haohuan, who was wearing a T-shirt with the word "Hong Kong Independence", said exactly this when being interviewed.
Previously, Chen Haohuan, former Democratic Party chairmen Wu Chi-wai and Leung Kwok-hung were accused of holding a press conference outside the Court of Final Appeal last year after the police opposed the "July 1" march application, calling on the public to participate in the march, and were accused of inciting the organization and participation. Chen pleaded guilty in the District Court on October 7 to three charges including unauthorized assembly and was sentenced to 12 months in prison.
Looking back on what Chen Haohuan said back then, and now that he is finally in jail, is it considered that he got what he wanted?

"Ta Kung Pao" also revealed that at the scene of the violent incident in the Hong Kong Legislative Council Building on July 1, a person who took off his mask and "swore an oath" was caught on camera. It is worth mentioning that Yang Langyi was sentenced to 2 years in prison for setting fire outside the Hong Kong Legislative Council building in 2015.
The man in the recording shouted on the spot and instigated violent demonstrators to rush into the office of a member of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong (DAB) on the sixth floor of the Legislative Council, trying to steal the DAB's "voter registration information" and threatening to " I take all responsibility.”
Chairman of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong (DAB) Lee Wai-king has publicly expressed her support for amending the Fugitive Offenders Ordinance on many occasions, and went to the U.S. Consulate General in Hong Kong to petition on the afternoon of June 12, strongly opposing U.S. interference in China’s internal affairs. The Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong (DAB) stated that this amendment is a matter of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and does not allow any external forces to interfere in the internal affairs of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.
"Dagong.com" revealed that on July 1, only the lobby, first-floor conference hall and second-floor conference room of the Legislative Council building were damaged, while the offices of members on the sixth floor were not affected. DAB Chairman Li Huiqiong said that the Legislative Council Secretariat is currently handling the matter.

title: 今年“七一”香港发生重大变化，令西方媒体哀嚎不已
translation:
In the past two days, many Western media have reported on the participation of Hong Kong independence elements in the "July 1" parade organized by the Hong Kong opposition and anti-mainland forces.
However, a change in this year's parade made these Western media feel very "depressed"...
"Hong Kong's annual march has hit a record low in participation this year," British Reuters wrote in its report.
The British media also said that although the organizers of the event said that there were 50,000 people marching this year, the police said that the number was 9,800. Both parties also stated that the participants in this march were the largest in the history of this march that began in 2003. The lowest time.
The British BBC also reported this situation with the title "Hong Kong Parade Hits New Low". However, this British media, which loves BB Hong Kong the most, attributed the reason to the fact that "a number of well-known democrats have been imprisoned by the government in the past year."
However, data from the Hong Kong police and third parties show that the number of people participating in Hong Kong's "July 1" demonstrations has been declining over the past four years. Among them, the number of participants in 2015 had already reached a record low at that time - at that time, those "democrats" who disrupted the rule of law in Hong Kong, incited confrontation between Hong Kong and the mainland, and even incited Hong Kong independence had not yet been punished by law.
And every year after 2015, the number of participants in the parade has continued to set new "historically low" records.
Therefore, from the data point of view, the continuous decrease in the number of people in Hong Kong's "July 1" demonstrations is more indicative that in addition to the anti-mainland and even anti-China forces in Hong Kong and foreign countries, the Hong Kong people are losing interest in this demonstration that is becoming increasingly paranoid and constantly creating social confrontation and hatred. interest.

title: 香港修例风波回望：当青年被绑上暴力战车
translation:
On September 22, 2019, parents participated in the "Anti-Violence, Protect Schools" rally in Chater Garden, Hong Kong.
"Actually, where is there any 'illegal means' in Hong Kong today? For those politicians who are packaged and supported by external forces, the real meaning of this word is 'illegal means'." A political commentator said explain.
The manipulators and "political stars" behind the scenes are protected by unscrupulous lawyers, who help them avoid legal restrictions in every possible way, and are also provided with various political benefits and financial gifts from foreign forces. But those young people who are not deeply involved in the world are getting behind bars, tears, and their futures are ruined. The psychological torture may stay with many people for their entire lives.
The Commissioner of Police of the SAR Government, Tang Bingqiang, pointed out that some violent incidents during the anti-amendment demonstrations essentially contained behavioral elements of "domestic terrorism". However, instead of condemning it, some people in society "heroicize" and "romanticize" violent acts, pushing others to commit crimes while enjoying political dividends themselves.
Leung Chun-ying, Vice Chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and former Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, pointedly pointed out that young people are misled by the "big platform" (organizations and manipulators), and only after being arrested do they know that they have become "cannon fodder", while "violating the law and upholding justice" has always been just a political scam. .

The Hong Kong Federation of Guangdong Associations issued a position statement, saying it was shocked by the protesters' attack and destruction of the Legislative Council building. Deng Qinghe, the association's first executive chairman, described the incident as the most serious violent incident since the handover, undermining the rule of law on which Hong Kong relies for stability. We strongly demand that the police investigate violent acts committed by demonstrators in accordance with the law, and firmly support the government and the police in enforcing the law.
Gong Junlong, chairman of the association, said that Western countries, led by the United States, have been supporting the demonstrators financially and politically, and reiterated that this was definitely a violent incident.
The Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce pointed out that citizens have the right to express their personal opinions, but under any circumstances, violence will never be tolerated and the rule of law must be respected and upheld. The Chinese Manufacturers' Association of Hong Kong also issued a statement strongly condemning the demonstrators' violent attack on the Legislative Council.
According to a report by Hong Kong's Sing Tao Daily on July 3, four police staff representatives met with the media on the 2nd regarding the destruction of the Legislative Council building by demonstrators. Lam Chi-wai, chairman of the Hong Kong Police Junior Officers Association, criticized some people who undermined the rule of law in the name of democracy.
According to reports, the Superintendents’ Association, the Police Inspectors’ Association, the Overseas Inspectors’ Association and the Police Junior Officers’ Association also issued a joint statement condemning the demonstrators who broke into and damaged the Legislative Council building the day before yesterday. Representatives of four police staff also met with the media. Lin Zhiwei said that the association urged the management to "do all they can to arrest the rioters and bring them to justice."
The report pointed out that Chen Mingde, chairman of the Police Superintendents Association, stressed that measures would be taken to deal with relevant behaviors. Ng Wai-kee, chairman of the Local Inspectorate, emphasized that the demonstrators would pay a heavy price. He condemned the demonstrators in the strongest terms for openly challenging the rule of law. He denounced some people who undermined the rule of law in the name of democracy. "Hong Kong history will evaluate their actions."

title: Hong Kong protests: The flashpoints in a year of anger

An end to Hong Kong as we know it? | Hub
暴徒冲击香港立法会大楼：11人被拘捕6人法院提堂
translation:
Hong Kong's illegal "Occupy Central" movement lasted for 53 days. In the early morning of November 19, a group of radical demonstrators launched a violent attack and smashed the glass of the SAR Legislative Council building with iron fences and cement bricks. The picture shows demonstrators blocking the police.
China News Service, Hong Kong, November 21 (Xinhua) After thugs stormed the Legislative Council building of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, another person was arrested on the 21st, bringing the number of arrests to 11 so far. Among them, six people were charged and appeared in court at the Eastern District Magistrates' Court on the 21st.

In the early morning of the 19th, radical demonstrators wearing helmets, goggles, masks, and masks violently attacked the Legislative Council building multiple times with iron fences, bricks, drain covers, trash cans, etc. The building was damaged in many places, with glass broken and brick walls broken. The rioters also tried to prevent the police from enforcing the law and provoked the police officers. Three police officers were injured. The Hong Kong SAR government, members of the Legislative Council, and various political groups have condemned the rioters' actions. The police launched a comprehensive investigation and people were arrested one after another.

Information provided by the police shows that the 11 people arrested so far, ranging in age from 17 to 54, were suspected of "criminal damage", "assaulting a police officer", "accessing computers with criminal or dishonest intent", and "illegal assembly" ". Six of them were escorted by police vehicles to the Eastern District Magistrates' Court on the 21st and were charged with "criminal damage" and "assaulting a police officer" respectively.

While the police continue to investigate the case of rioters attacking the Legislative Council building, Hong Kong's illegal "Occupy Central" has lasted for 55 days. Demonstrators who held illegal gatherings in Admiralty and Mong Kok continued to occupy traffic arteries. In the early morning of the 19th, demonstrators even blocked the police from going to the Legislative Council building to stop the mob from attacking.

Most members of the Hong Kong SAR Legislative Council believe that the so-called "peaceful Occupy Central" movement has completely gone bankrupt. The reason for this situation is that the occupiers continued to occupy the road against public opinion and were unwilling to end the occupation. In addition, the organizers of the action and some politicians who supported the action distorted the concept of the rule of law and spread the fallacy that there is no need to abide by the law. Occupy actions are exactly the same as violent attacks on the Legislative Council, which undermine the essence of the rule of law.

title: Hong Kong: One year after China passed the national security law, residents feel Beijing’s tightening grip | CNN
Interview: Radical protesters responsible for violence in Hong Kong, expert says
香港警方再拘4人 冲击立法会暴力分子大起底
translation:
The 4 arrested were from “passionate citizens”

According to a report by Hong Kong's "Wen Wei Po" on the 20th, the police arrested 6 demonstrators who participated in the smash-up on the 19th. Although 4 of them did not admit which group they belonged to, various investigations showed that they often participated in activities organized by "Hot-Blooded Citizens" and should is its member. Among them, the person wearing red clothes and taking the lead in smashing the glass door of the Legislative Council with an iron horse was the host of the "Hot Blood Times" who participated in the Mong Kok street forum earlier and was nicknamed "The French Guy". According to the report, as early as the beginning of this month, the "passionate citizens" were actively planning to "do a major event that would attract the attention of the whole Hong Kong." They stormed the Legislative Council this time because they were unwilling to accept that Mong Kok was about to be cleared, so they went to Admiralty to cause trouble and will The escalation of actions is to arouse public attention on the one hand; on the other hand, it is reaching out to the "occupied area" of Admiralty in an attempt to expand its territory. "Oriental Daily" stated that members of the "Hot-Blooded Citizen" are known as the "Mask Party" because they often wear masks in action. The six people arrested were between the ages of 18 and 24. Five of them were cynical young people with low education and addicted to the Internet. One of them had a criminal record for having sex with an underage girl, and the others had no criminal record.

"Hot-Blooded Citizens" is an extremely radical group of the Hong Kong opposition. Its founders are pan-democratic Legislative Council member Huang Yu-min (observer website note: has caused incidents such as "throwing a cup at the Chief Executive"), Huang Yangda and his wife Chen Xiuhui, etc. They operate the "Hot Blood Times" website, online channels and publications, and at the same time host and co-organize a number of "social activities" throughout Hong Kong, attracting many "double losers" and unemployed people to join. Instigated by Huang Yumin and Huang Yangda, although there are not many of them, it is said that more than 300 people have participated in the "occupation" operations in various districts, but they have always played a role in directly confronting the police and instigating violent incidents. Dozens of them are "death squads" and "Stormtrooper" members generally prepare helmets, goggles, masks, pointed umbrellas, gloves and other equipment. When the "Occupy Central" movement broke out on September 28, Huang Yangda stood on a ladder and encouraged demonstrators to continuously attack the police defense line, becoming one of the most active troublemakers at the scene. Although Huang Yangta claimed that he acted independently and had no contact with the Federation of Students, Scholar Thought and the "Three Ugly Occupy Central" groups, they coordinated in early October, and the "passionate citizens" were mainly responsible for Mong Kok. After the police successfully cleared some roadblocks on Nathan Road in the early morning of October 17, "hot-blooded citizens" formed a "frontline stormtrooper team" and attacked the police that night and at midnight on the 18th. Afterwards, they instigated many violent incidents, making Mong Kok a The most dangerous place in Hong Kong.

title: 香港“七一游行”凌晨清场，警方共拘捕511名滋事者
translation:
The police said the force used in the clearance was appropriate and necessary

        As for some of the arrested persons, Chief Superintendent of the Public Relations Division of the Hong Kong Police, Hui Chun-tak, said that the police may not necessarily prosecute immediately, but will handle them according to established procedures, depending on the nature of the case and the evidence available to the police. He said that the force used by the police during the clearance operation was appropriate and necessary.

        He said that the police had repeatedly advised and warned the protesters, but the demonstrators still refused to leave. The police officers at the scene had no choice but to use appropriate and necessary force. The police expressed regret for their uncooperative attitude and illegal behavior.

        Some demonstrators were taken to Wong Chuk Hang Police College. After registering their personal information, they were taken to Welfare Road in Wong Chuk Hang by tour buses in batches, and then left on their own.

        The demonstrator who was allowed to leave said that the police did not record a statement and did not need to pay bail. He said that he only received a "warning notice" issued by the police, stating that they were arrested for participating in unauthorized assemblies and causing obstruction to public places. He was temporarily released with the possibility of future prosecution.

惊讶！BBC抢先报道乱港组织解散，把“称XXXXX”发出来了！
translation:
The BBC has repeatedly published unfair, unobjective, and irresponsible reports. Recently, the BBC reported that institutional research showed that hundreds of fake accounts on social media are promoting narratives that are favorable to China and discrediting opponents of the Chinese government. The Chinese Embassy in the UK responded by saying that we advise the BBC and relevant institutions to cherish their own image and credibility, stop malicious slander against China, and abide by the principles of objective, truthful and accurate news reporting. Otherwise, you will encounter opposition and resistance from more people.

As for the "Democratic Front", it was established in 2002. It initially carried out opposition activities against the legislation of Article 23 of the Basic Law. After the "July 1" march in 2003, it gradually became a joint platform for the opposition, gathering almost all the opposition parties. member. During the 2019 "revision disturbance", the "Democratic Front" instigated demonstrations, and thugs stormed the SAR government headquarters, surrounded the Legislative Council, and set fire to more than 10 locations on Hong Kong Island. A march initiated by the Democratic Front from Tsim Sha Tsui to West Kowloon Station also turned into a riot in Kowloon.

Some Hong Kong media revealed that the Democratic Front has been colluding with foreign forces to undermine the administration of the SAR government. In April 2013, the National Endowment for Democracy (NED) and others held the "Eighth Ethnic Youth Leaders Training Camp" in Taipei. Among those invited to participate was the then convener of the Democratic Front, Yang Zhengxian. In 2019, the Democratic Front wrote to 61 foreign consulates general in Hong Kong and the European Union Office in Hong Kong and Macao, inciting countries to issue travel warnings against Hong Kong and openly slandering "one country, two systems." In December 2020, the Democratic Front, together with 26 groups including the Stake Alliance, wrote to the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights, requesting the United Nations to investigate multiple cases of so-called "torture."

According to a report by Oriental Daily on the 12th, in June 2019, the Democratic Front had 48 member groups, but now only 8 remain. In early March this year, some foreign media claimed that the Democratic Front was being investigated for violating the national security law and might soon be banned by the SAR government. Soon, members of many groups withdrew from the "Democratic Front" one after another, including street workers, the Association for Democracy, the Civic Party, the Democratic Party, etc.

Hong Kong Police Commissioner Xiao Zeyi said on the 12th that he would investigate whether the "Democratic Front" is suspected of violating Hong Kong's national security law. He revealed that the police have been collecting evidence and will take action against illegal organizations in accordance with the law at any time. He emphasized that offenders should not think that they can "escape" by disbanding.

title: AP PHOTOS: The rise and fall of Hong Kong's July 1 protests | AP News
部分冲击香港立法会的暴徒已躲至台湾！前特首质问：他们为啥急着出逃？
translation:
More than 30 rioters who stormed the Hong Kong Legislative Council on July 1 and wreaked havoc have fled to Taiwan to escape!

Some members of the Legislative Council pointed out that this group of thugs was able to obtain "assistance" from the Taiwan authorities in a short period of time, proving that some of the Hong Kong opposition and illegal demonstrators are indeed connected with overseas political forces.
According to a report by Hong Kong media "Ta Kung Pao" on the 19th, according to internal reports from the opposition, more than 30 thugs who forced their way into the Legislative Council on July 1 and wreaked havoc have fled to Taiwan and have contacted relevant agencies of the Taiwan authorities. It is reported that most of the escaped thugs are students, some are seeking "asylum", and some are planning to study in Taiwan to extend their stay.

According to Global Network, Tsai Ing-wen has previously said that if illegal demonstrators in Hong Kong seek "political asylum," Taiwan will deal with them appropriately and in a humane manner. At the press conference of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs held on the 19th, spokesman Geng Shuang responded: "I advise some people on the island not to jump out and pretend to be compassionate at this time. They themselves are just clay Buddhas."

In fact, after the violent attack on the Legislative Council on July 1, relevant posts were posted online, claiming that illegal demonstrators who participated in the violent attack had left Hong Kong by plane that night. Later reports pointed out that Liang Jiping, a "Hong Kong independence" element who incited others to stay behind and advocated "dropping the charges against the protesters" that day, had booked his flight tickets in advance and flew to Taipei the next day.

In addition, after the destruction of the Legislative Council, a number of posts appeared on Hong Kong social media instructing illegal demonstrators how to seek "asylum" in Taiwan.

In this regard, Hong Kong Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong Legislative Council member Ge Peifan pointed out that the absconders claim to love Hong Kong and are righteous, but they leave immediately when there is a problem, evading responsibility and showing no commitment. She also noticed that the absconders were able to receive assistance in Taiwan within a short period of time, proving that they were indeed connected to overseas political forces.

translation:
Hong Kong's "Social Democratic League", "People Power", "Hong Kong People's Liberation Army" and other opposition groups recently launched a demonstration. After the demonstration, serious internal strife broke out, and internal members provoked each other to fight. It was criticized as another "farce".

According to Hong Kong media reports, several radical organizations such as the "Social Democratic League" failed to illegally attack Government House after the demonstration on the evening of July 1 and withdrew to the SAR Court of Final Appeal for "discussions." During this period, Zhou Shufeng, the radical local president of the Chinese University Student Union, was dissatisfied with the "Social Democratic League" and others' refusal to block the road. title: 香港修例风波回望：当青年被绑上暴力战车
translation:
The network that incites violence
In June and July 2019, some anti-extradition law demonstrators in Hong Kong clashed with law enforcement police. Subsequently, the personal and family information of some police officers was made public on the Internet, including the names, ID numbers and families of the police officers and their family members. Address, etc.
Some police officers said that they and their families received a large number of harassing and threatening calls and text messages. According to statistics, 150 cases were transferred to the Office of the Privacy Commissioner for Personal Data in a short period of time.
Amid the turmoil over the amendment bill, some online forums and social media in Hong Kong have become breeding grounds for thugs and classrooms for inciting atrocities, becoming the biggest source of chaos in Hong Kong. Faced with Hong Kong teenagers who have grown up with the Internet and are deeply dependent on it, as long as they seize the right to speak online through various means, constantly cater to their interests and preferences, and stimulate their extremes and hatred, they can trap their hearts and incite them. They roam the streets.
A survey by the Hong Kong Federation of Youth Groups found that nearly 90% of Hong Kong youth own smartphones and use them for an average of 3.5 hours a day. Social media represented by Facebook has become the most commonly used platform by Hong Kong youth, and nearly half of Hong Kong youth use it as the main source of information on public affairs.
On social platforms such as Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube in Hong Kong, rumors are costless and lies are flying everywhere. "Police sexually assaulted an arrested woman", "Police undercover threw incendiary bombs", "People died at Prince Edward Station on August 31"... Internet rumors pushed some young people who did not know what was going on into an inexplicable "revenge" mood and lost their rational thinking. and independent judgment. Even if the police and relevant departments provide evidence to prove that the online rumors are completely false, the inciters continue to spread the rumors online and conduct "memorial" activities online and offline.
Malicious subversion and arrogance are the most common means to incite violence and inspire hatred and fear. In August, some maliciously modified pictures and videos were circulated online. An image shows a family being chased by riot police at New Town Plaza in Sha Tin. The video played by the police at the press conference clearly showed that the police were escorting them to a safe place. The family later publicly thanked the police for protecting them.
In a video of the demonstration played by the police, a young man suddenly jumped off the bridge, and multiple police officers caught him in time to avoid a tragedy. However, the incident was described online as "the police pushing the young man off the bridge".
Violent instigation is not considered strange on the Internet, and it has even turned into violent and terrorist teaching with a terrorist nature. Social media represented by the "Lian Deng" online discussion forum and "Telegram" have become the source and command post of "black terror" and the base camp for instigating atrocities.
Log into these two online platforms and you will be flooded with inciting posts. Want to make your own assault weapon and use it correctly? There are graphic or video tutorials here to teach you "step by step" how to make and use incendiary bombs, smoke bombs, improvised bombs, and corrosive liquid bombs. In addition, there are "dog sticks", bows and arrows, modified slingshots... "Eighteen kinds of weapons" used by black-clad thugs when they attack police and siege institutions. You can find "warfare instruction manuals" here.
"The online public opinion environment in Hong Kong is particularly bad." Chen Zhihao, vice chairman of the Hong Kong Youth Current Affairs Commentators Association, felt deeply. "The opposition is very comfortable on the popular Internet, and all kinds of rumors and slanderous things can be circulated unimpeded."

title: Hong Kong police thwart protests set for China's national day - The Washington Post
香港修例风波回望：当青年被绑上暴力战车
translation:
distorted education
On October 13, 2019, black-clad thugs wreaked havoc in many places in Hong Kong. Police officer Ali (pseudonym) and his colleagues were ordered to handle a criminal damage case at Kwun Tong MTR station. Suddenly a sharp blade stuck out from the crowd and stabbed Ali in the neck.
The person who injured someone with a knife was actually an 18-year-old sixth form student.
More than a month later, Ali sadly told reporters on his hospital bed: "In the past few months, some college and middle school students have used very violent methods to attack police and citizens, and destroyed shops. I think there is something wrong with Hong Kong's education."
When Ali was interviewed by reporters at the Hong Kong Police Headquarters, the wound on his neck was clearly visible (photo taken on November 27, 2019). (Photo by Xinhua News Agency reporter Li Zhen)
Teenagers are the most enthusiastic group in the turmoil over the extradition bill. They wantonly set fires and vandalism, smashed shops, destroyed public facilities, threw petrol bombs, and attacked police and citizens.
But what is ridiculous is that after some of them were punished by the police according to law, some schools not only did not criticize their illegal and violent behavior, but instead issued a statement accusing "the police of violating regulations and exceeding their authority" and calling on all walks of life to "accept" the violent students.
There are many teachers in Hong Kong who incite violence and commit violence. Huang Junyu, president of the Hong Kong Federation of Educators, said that there are more than 60,000 teachers in primary and secondary schools in Hong Kong, including some teachers with more radical ideas. Although they are small in number, they have great energy. They use the platform to carry out political propaganda and persuade some immature young people and even minors to take to the streets. The most violent members among them were trained to be "brave" men who did not distinguish right from wrong and despised the law.
According to statistics from the education department of the Hong Kong SAR government, from June last year to the end of January this year, a total of 171 complaints were received about possible professional misconduct by teachers, most of which involved making inappropriate remarks such as hatred and curses. A middle school assistant principal actually cursed that "a gangster policeman will kill his whole family" and "the policeman's children will not survive until the age of seven." Public opinion in Hong Kong called this a "shame on the education sector."
As the largest single-industry trade union in Hong Kong and the organization with the largest number of participating members, the Hong Kong "Teachers' Association" has long been controlled by opposition forces. The leader of the organization, Ye Jianyuan, once expressed support for middle school students in promoting "Hong Kong independence" on campus, beautifying it as "having independent opinions, having personal opinions and caring about current affairs."
“If Hong Kong’s education is ‘sick’, then there is something wrong with the educators first.” Gu Minkang, former deputy dean of the School of Law of City University of Hong Kong, wrote in an article.
In addition to educators, there are also many problems with teaching content. "Hong Kong lacks national education with positive guidance, but is full of negative expressions of the opposition and 'education' full of hatred." said Deng Fei, principal of Hong Kong Island Secondary School in Tseung Kwan O.

Xinhua Headlines: Hong Kong people express support for police, calling for end to violence
香港立法会建制派议员强烈谴责暴力冲击立法会行为
translation:
On July 1, some radicals in Hong Kong violently attacked and occupied the Legislative Council building, wreaking havoc on the facilities inside the Legislative Council chamber. On the 2nd, all pro-establishment members of the Legislative Council severely condemned this serious illegal behavior. At the same time, they hope that the police will strictly enforce the law and the lawbreakers will be punished as soon as possible.
Liao Changjiang, the convener of the pro-establishment members of the Legislative Council, said that day that the actions of criminals caused unprecedented damage to the facilities of the Legislative Council. The pro-establishment faction unanimously issued the strongest condemnation, and this serious illegal behavior has also seriously affected people's livelihood. "We I went to see it and it was devastated. The elevators were damaged and many computers were damaged. We, the pro-establishment members of the Legislative Council, condemned this violence in the strongest terms. But the biggest issue now is financial allocation, and many of them are related to people's livelihood. Some of the funding problems cannot be solved, so it not only affects the Legislative Council, but also seriously affects people’s livelihood.”
Sandra Ip, a member of the pro-establishment faction of the Legislative Council and chairperson of the Hong Kong New Democratic Party, also strongly condemned the series of lawless and vandalistic activities that occurred in the Legislative Council building. She said that the violent acts destroyed Hong Kong's reputation and the interests of citizens, and hoped that the police would take action as soon as possible. Bring the criminals to justice. "I strongly condemn this unprecedented violent incident, which has greatly affected the overall security of Hong Kong and the interests of the general public. It needs to be strongly condemned. I also hope that the police will arrest the criminals as soon as possible." Bring to justice."
At a press conference held by pro-establishment members of the Legislative Council on the 2nd, Lee Wai-king, a pro-establishment member of the Legislative Council and chairman of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong, also emphasized that the Legislative Council is a symbol of the rule of law in Hong Kong, but this time it was vandalized and she expected the police to strictly enforce the law. , "The Legislative Council is a symbol of the rule of law in Hong Kong. Yesterday, everyone saw the wanton destruction of the Legislative Council. We hereby condemn in the strongest possible terms all serious illegal acts of violence. From the afternoon of (July 1) until the evening, everyone Seeing (criminals) throwing corrosive liquids and powders, and then rushing to the Legislative Council to cause wanton destruction is an insult to the Legislative Council and an insult to the rule of law in Hong Kong. "We demand that the police strictly enforce the law."

title: Woman's courage inspires Hong Kong society against violence

华春莹9分钟答记者问 详解为何美国会和香港暴乱场景相似但反应不同
translation:
There are two differences between the attack on the Legislative Council in Hong Kong and the riots in the U.S. Congress.
Hua Chunying said, I have noticed that some media said that the attack on the Legislative Council in Hong Kong is different from what will happen in the United States and should not be compared. If there are differences between the two, I think there are at least two differences:
First, the thugs who attacked the Hong Kong Legislative Council in July 2019 smashed and vandalized the legislative body, hunted down innocent people, and attacked the police with petrol bombs and knives. Such crimes are more serious and more vicious than climbing on the outer wall of the Congress and storming into the Congress in the United States. They should be defined as "thugs" and "terrorists" and should be severely punished by law.
Second, what happened in the U.S. Congress was organized by the Americans themselves, while what happened in Hong Kong was instigated, planned, organized, directed and implemented by external forces, and some people in the United States played a very disgraceful role in it. .
